trans-unit.source: Get Blob Service Stats
trans-unit.target: Get Blob Service Stats

trans-unit.source: Get Blob Service Stats
trans-unit.target: Get Blob Service Stats

trans-unit.source: The <languageKeyword>Get Blob Service Stats</languageKeyword> operation retrieves statistics related to replication for the Blob service.
trans-unit.target: The <languageKeyword>Get Blob Service Stats</languageKeyword> operation retrieves statistics related to replication for the Blob service.

trans-unit.source: It is only available on the secondary location endpoint when read-access geo-redundant replication is enabled for the storage account.
trans-unit.target: It is only available on the secondary location endpoint when read-access geo-redundant replication is enabled for the storage account.

trans-unit.source: Request
trans-unit.target: Request

trans-unit.source: The <languageKeyword>Get Blob Service Stats</languageKeyword> request may be constructed as follows.
trans-unit.target: The <languageKeyword>Get Blob Service Stats</languageKeyword> request may be constructed as follows.

trans-unit.source: HTTPS is recommended.
trans-unit.target: HTTPS is recommended.

trans-unit.source: Replace <codeInline>myaccount</codeInline> with the name of your storage account, and note that the <codeInline>-secondary</codeInline> suffix is required:
trans-unit.target: Replace <codeInline>myaccount</codeInline> with the name of your storage account, and note that the <codeInline>-secondary</codeInline> suffix is required:

trans-unit.target: Note that the URI must always include the forward slash (/) to separate the host name from the path and query portions of the URI.

trans-unit.source: In the case of this operation, the path portion of the URI is empty.
trans-unit.target: In the case of this operation, the path portion of the URI is empty.

trans-unit.source: Status Code
trans-unit.target: Status Code

trans-unit.source: A successful operation returns status code 200 (OK).
trans-unit.target: A successful operation returns status code 200 (OK).

trans-unit.source: When called on secondary location endpoint which is not enabled for secondary read, it will return Http status code of 403 with <languageKeyword>InsufficientAccountPermissions</languageKeyword> error.
trans-unit.target: When called on secondary location endpoint which is not enabled for secondary read, it will return Http status code of 403 with <languageKeyword>InsufficientAccountPermissions</languageKeyword> error.

trans-unit.target: For information about status codes, see <externalLink><linkText>Service Management Status and Error Codes</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/ee460801.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.target: Response Body

trans-unit.target: The format of the response body is as follows:

trans-unit.source: The following table describes the elements of the response body:
trans-unit.target: The following table describes the elements of the response body:

trans-unit.source: Response Header
trans-unit.target: Response Header

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: The status of the secondary location.
trans-unit.target: The status of the secondary location.

trans-unit.source: Possible values are:
trans-unit.target: Possible values are:

trans-unit.source: <codeInline>live</codeInline>: Indicates that the secondary location is active and operational.
trans-unit.target: <codeInline>live</codeInline>: Indicates that the secondary location is active and operational.

trans-unit.source: <codeInline>bootstrap</codeInline>: Indicates initial synchronization from the primary location to the secondary location is in progress.
trans-unit.target: <codeInline>bootstrap</codeInline>: Indicates initial synchronization from the primary location to the secondary location is in progress.

trans-unit.source: This typically occurs when replication is first enabled.
trans-unit.target: This typically occurs when replication is first enabled.

trans-unit.source: unavailable: Indicates that the secondary location is temporarily unavailable.
trans-unit.target: unavailable: Indicates that the secondary location is temporarily unavailable.

trans-unit.source: A GMT date/time value, to the second.
trans-unit.target: A GMT date/time value, to the second.

trans-unit.source: All primary writes preceding this value are guaranteed to be available for read operations at the secondary.
trans-unit.target: All primary writes preceding this value are guaranteed to be available for read operations at the secondary.

trans-unit.source: Primary writes after this point in time may or may not be available for reads.
trans-unit.target: Primary writes after this point in time may or may not be available for reads.

trans-unit.source: The value may be empty if <parameterReference>LastSyncTime</parameterReference> is not available.
trans-unit.target: The value may be empty if <parameterReference>LastSyncTime</parameterReference> is not available.

trans-unit.source: This can happen if the replication status is <codeInline>bootstrap</codeInline> or <codeInline>unavailable</codeInline>.
trans-unit.target: This can happen if the replication status is <codeInline>bootstrap</codeInline> or <codeInline>unavailable</codeInline>.

trans-unit.source: Although geo-replication is continuously enabled, the <parameterReference>LastSyncTime</parameterReference> result may reflect a cached value from the service that is refreshed every few minutes.
trans-unit.target: Although geo-replication is continuously enabled, the <parameterReference>LastSyncTime</parameterReference> result may reflect a cached value from the service that is refreshed every few minutes.

trans-unit.source: Authorization
trans-unit.target: Authorization

trans-unit.source: Only the account owner may call this operation.
trans-unit.target: Only the account owner may call this operation.

trans-unit.source: Remarks
trans-unit.target: Remarks

trans-unit.source: With geo-redundant replication, Azure Storage maintains your data durable in two locations.
trans-unit.target: With geo-redundant replication, Azure Storage maintains your data durable in two locations.

trans-unit.source: In both locations, Azure Storage constantly maintains multiple healthy replicas of your data.
trans-unit.target: In both locations, Azure Storage constantly maintains multiple healthy replicas of your data.

trans-unit.source: The location where you read, create, update, or delete data is the <newTerm>primary</newTerm> storage account location.
trans-unit.target: The location where you read, create, update, or delete data is the <newTerm>primary</newTerm> storage account location.

trans-unit.source: The primary location exists in the region you choose at the time you create an account via the Azure Management Azure Portal, for example, <ui>North Central US</ui>.
trans-unit.target: The primary location exists in the region you choose at the time you create an account via the Azure Management Azure Portal, for example, <ui>North Central US</ui>.

trans-unit.source: The location to which your data is replicated is the <newTerm>secondary</newTerm> location.
trans-unit.target: The location to which your data is replicated is the <newTerm>secondary</newTerm> location.

trans-unit.source: The secondary location is automatically determined based on the location of the primary; it is in a second data center that resides in the same region as the primary location.
trans-unit.target: The secondary location is automatically determined based on the location of the primary; it is in a second data center that resides in the same region as the primary location.

trans-unit.source: Read-only access is available from the secondary location, if <newTerm>read-access geo-redundant replication</newTerm> is enabled for your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Read-only access is available from the secondary location, if <newTerm>read-access geo-redundant replication</newTerm> is enabled for your storage account.

trans-unit.source: For more details about read-access geo-redundant replication, see the <externalLink><linkText>Azure Storage Team Blog</linkText><linkUri>http://blogs.msdn.com/b/windowsazurestorage/archive/2013/12/04/introducing-read-access-geo-replicated-storage-ra-grs-for-windows-azure-storage.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more details about read-access geo-redundant replication, see the <externalLink><linkText>Azure Storage Team Blog</linkText><linkUri>http://blogs.msdn.com/b/windowsazurestorage/archive/2013/12/04/introducing-read-access-geo-replicated-storage-ra-grs-for-windows-azure-storage.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: To construct a request for a read operation against the secondary endpoint, append <codeInline>-secondary</codeInline> as a suffix to the account name in the URI that you use to read from Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: To construct a request for a read operation against the secondary endpoint, append <codeInline>-secondary</codeInline> as a suffix to the account name in the URI that you use to read from Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: For example, a secondary URI for the <link xlink:href="a3e943b4-5745-4e64-9d6f-728bbefbd5ee" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Get Blob (REST API)</link> operation will be similar to <codeInline>https://myaccount-secondary.blob.core.windows.net/mycontainer/myblob</codeInline>.
trans-unit.target: For example, a secondary URI for the <link xlink:href="a3e943b4-5745-4e64-9d6f-728bbefbd5ee" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Get Blob (REST API)</link> operation will be similar to <codeInline>https://myaccount-secondary.blob.core.windows.net/mycontainer/myblob</codeInline>.
